title: How to Make a Halo 3 Machinima

steps.headline: Have an  Xbox 360, television, and Video Capture Card, such as Dazzle.
steps.description: They cost from 70-100 dollars. Video capture cards usually have Red White Yellow and S-Video, and have a USB cord coming out the other end.

steps.headline: Know that if your TV has computer compatible output such as S-Video, use that instead of a Video Capture Card.
steps.description: Do some research before you buy.

steps.headline: Study film techniques.
steps.description: The high-standard Halo 3 Machinima directors need the same knowledge as someone shooting a live-action movie. Make use of over-the-shoulder, close up camera angles, etc.

steps.headline: Think of a storyline.
steps.description: Is it going to be a lengthy movie or a series of short films? Is it a comedy, parody, or instructional movie? The point is, think of a script and write it down. Be original. No one likes copycats.

steps.headline: Using cast members other than yourself, via Xbox Live or whatever means of connection, you will have to set up recording dates.
steps.description: Act everything out. Halo 3 Theater mode doesn't record voice, so just record multiple takes of everything, you can sync it later.

steps.headline: Leave the Forge or Custom game, go into theater mode (without other players in your party) and record all the necessary video clips.
Hook up your cables to your computer (whether you use Dazzle or other means).
steps.description: Dazzle comes with a video capture program. Record all your saved clips from theater. You may want to get Red/White/Yellow splitters so you can view it on your TV and computer, because the dazzle screen is tiny and lags a little bit.

steps.headline: Record the voices, if there are any.
steps.description: Make sure there is no interference or background noise.

steps.headline: Start editing!
steps.description: Make sure you're familiar with your editing software, and watch it come together.

steps.headline: Get your video known.
steps.description: Many Machinima directors upload their work to YouTube or Machinima.com.

text: Have an  Xbox 360, television, and Video Capture Card, such as Dazzle. They cost from 70-100 dollars. Video capture cards usually have Red White Yellow and S-Video, and have a USB cord coming out the other end. Know that if your TV has computer compatible output such as S-Video, use that instead of a Video Capture Card. Do some research before you buy. Study film techniques. The high-standard Halo 3 Machinima directors need the same knowledge as someone shooting a live-action movie. Make use of over-the-shoulder, close up camera angles, etc. Think of a storyline. Is it going to be a lengthy movie or a series of short films? Is it a comedy, parody, or instructional movie? The point is, think of a script and write it down. Be original. No one likes copycats. Using cast members other than yourself, via Xbox Live or whatever means of connection, you will have to set up recording dates. Act everything out. Halo 3 Theater mode doesn't record voice, so just record multiple takes of everything, you can sync it later. Leave the Forge or Custom game, go into theater mode (without other players in your party) and record all the necessary video clips.  Hook up your cables to your computer (whether you use Dazzle or other means). Dazzle comes with a video capture program. Record all your saved clips from theater. You may want to get Red/White/Yellow splitters so you can view it on your TV and computer, because the dazzle screen is tiny and lags a little bit. Record the voices, if there are any. Make sure there is no interference or background noise. Start editing! Make sure you're familiar with your editing software, and watch it come together. Get your video known. Many Machinima directors upload their work to YouTube or Machinima.com.
